Suzuran Review | Bon Appetit

Most ramen is nowhere near this expensive, but most ramen is not both a gastronomic and aesthetic achievement. The menu is also unusually large and varied: Whereas almost every other shop in the country will focus on executing only one or two bowls to the best of its ability, Suzuran offers a coterie of expertly crafted bowls inspired by everything from sukiyaki to Sichuan hot pot.ORDER THE: standards to see what a simple bowl can be when taken to its most artistic conclusion: chashu men (topped with sliced pork), wontonmen (studded with dumplings), buta kakuni men (accompanied by big medallions of sweet braised pork belly), and tantanmen (the Japanese take on Chinese dan dan mian). Or order one of the deluxe bowls from the menu of house specials, though know that these items will demand a premium price.THE VIBE IS: sumptuous. Lights are dim and chairs are cushy. The counter is hewn wood and the kitchen never rises above a quiet hum. There is no ticket machine at a place this posh and food is ordered from a menu not a counter. This is a professional operation that has more in common with high-end sushi than a busy ramen shop.PRACTICAL STUFF: Open Monday to Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. for lunch and 6 p.m. to 11 p.m. for dinner. Closed on Sundays. There is no English menu and the staff does not speak English, but a picture menu is available for you to select from. The nearest subway station is Ebisu.Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneNo bok choy left behind.
